title: How to Make Arancini

steps.headline: Prepare your filling ingredients by chopping them into pieces no larger than a small grape.
Gather your 2 bowls.
steps.description: Beat the eggs in the first one, and pour the breadcrumbs into the second. On a tray sprinkle generously with rice flour.

steps.headline: Using an ice cream scoop or spoon, make balls out of the risotto.
steps.description: The size is not crucial, they can be nice the size of a large grape or walnut, up to a small apple size.

steps.headline: If the rice is hard and crumbly, allow it to come to room temperature.
steps.description: You can mix it in your very clean hand like you would mix Play Doh, or mash gently with a fork to make it come together.

steps.headline: Using your thumb or a small spoon, press a hole into the rice and put your filling in the hole.
steps.description: If your rice is of a consistency that it can close around the filling without breaking, do that, or just spoon more on. Kids are quite good assistants at this job.

steps.headline: When you have made them into balls, roll them in the rice flour, coating them evenly.
steps.description: The rice flour works well with the risotto to make a good coating. Its also helps makes them crispy.

steps.headline: Using a spoon, dip them in the beaten eggs, then transfer the ball into the breadcrumbs to coat.
steps.description: Put the crumbed arancini on your second tray until ready to fry.

steps.headline: Heat a large frying pan with oil, you may deep fry them in batches which is the traditional method, or pan fry them.
steps.description: It will take longer to pan fry than deep fry, but it is a little healthier.

steps.headline: When golden all over, transfer to some paper towel to drain any surplus oil.
Serve hot with salad and tomato relish.
steps.description: Well worth the effort and makes leftovers into a new meal and is great to introduce kids into cooking.

text: Prepare your filling ingredients by chopping them into pieces no larger than a small grape.  Gather your 2 bowls. Beat the eggs in the first one, and pour the breadcrumbs into the second. On a tray sprinkle generously with rice flour. Using an ice cream scoop or spoon, make balls out of the risotto. The size is not crucial, they can be nice the size of a large grape or walnut, up to a small apple size. If the rice is hard and crumbly, allow it to come to room temperature. You can mix it in your very clean hand like you would mix Play Doh, or mash gently with a fork to make it come together. Using your thumb or a small spoon, press a hole into the rice and put your filling in the hole. If your rice is of a consistency that it can close around the filling without breaking, do that, or just spoon more on. Kids are quite good assistants at this job. When you have made them into balls, roll them in the rice flour, coating them evenly. The rice flour works well with the risotto to make a good coating. Its also helps makes them crispy. Using a spoon, dip them in the beaten eggs, then transfer the ball into the breadcrumbs to coat. Put the crumbed arancini on your second tray until ready to fry. Heat a large frying pan with oil, you may deep fry them in batches which is the traditional method, or pan fry them. It will take longer to pan fry than deep fry, but it is a little healthier. When golden all over, transfer to some paper towel to drain any surplus oil.  Serve hot with salad and tomato relish. Well worth the effort and makes leftovers into a new meal and is great to introduce kids into cooking.
